text: This is an unusual one but I am wondering out of those on here who are profitable AND maintain a day job AND make more off betfair than you do from your salary, how do you maintain your motivation for the day job?? I am really struggling and recently have had to start commuting to London 3 days a week now that the country seems to think the pandemic is over. This is costing me 12 hours a week and I have been generating 4x my salary on Betfair for the last few months and really struggling to be motivated. Commuting is dreadful. As a young man I loved London. As a not young/not old man I consider it largely to be a shithole these days. Any advice????

text: Quit the job?

elements.text: Quit the job?

text: Its possible but always at the back of my mind is the worry that Betfair won't be around forever. Particularly in light of these new affordability limits and applying loss/deposit limits on anyone under 25. I think it may take a while before we see the effects of that. It all seems a little bit uncertain.

text: <@U02FJKSKJT0> has joined the channel

This is nothing new, it's always uncertain.

Until quite recently I was always worried about betting going tits up for one reason or another. The cross matcher, the sportsbook, equine flu, the decline of racing, more competition. Hell when they first mooted the GPS feed I was scared of that. It's always been ok. There are challenges from time to time but you get through them and new opportunities come along too.

When you think about it it wouldn't be any different if you were running a normal business - anyone for poultry farming? You can get blind sided by random shit whatever you do. If anything betting has been an unusually stable "career" through the pandemic - at least if you're into horse racing.

I'm not going to say "_don't worry_" because I know that I speak from a position of relative security and it feels different if your house is at risk but I will say that this is normal and that any anxiety you feel is poorly spent.

I'm not going to say "
don't worry
" because I know that I speak from a position of relative security and it feels different if your house is at risk but I will say that this is normal and that any anxiety you feel is poorly spent.

text: Yes this I think is spot on. As I get older I realise that the most important things are health and time. Making money via automation on Betfair really does give you time and freedom from the rat rate. Also growing increasingly aware that it is important to live in the present rather than worrying about the future etc because nobody knows what is around the corner there. As such I REALLY resent those hours in the week where I am walking to/from the train station or sitting on a train bored shitless. I guess my biggest concern is having a CV gap to be honest.

text: Having been someone who sits on both sides of the interview table in the past I know how some people view CV gaps though. I suppose worst case scenario I could retrain as a maths teacher. They will always be looking for someone to do that thankless task

text: I think if for one reason or other this didnt work out / or I wanted to return to a "normal" job, I would put it on my CV as something im proud of, right at the top ,above all my qualifications (that are pointless in my view). whilst gambling is frowned upon by some, the skills required to be a successful automated person are very transferable / wanted and your implementation / code will demonstrate your real world examples of your ability (vs someone who followed a tutorial and copied the code etc).

text:
Obviously how you feel about it depends on what your overall position is in terms of finances, family and so on but if you're being sensible and putting money aside so that you could cover a gap without income then I think you can dial your worrying right down because the reality is that you will always get through. It might take longer to get a job or you might have to do something you don't love for a bit whilst you re-establish yourself but you'll get through. None of us is  watching the Taliban tighten the noose or trying to cross the channel on a lilo.

When I occasionally expressed anxiety about this sort of thing to my friends in the past they used to laugh at me because from where they were sitting it was obvious that I'd be fine. It's always obvious that other people will be fine it just never feels that way.

I don't know if it's really a good idea for you to quit your job if I'm honest - just because your record of making profits is relatively short. However you do decide to do that you could explain to your employer that you just don't need a job, offer a very long notice period, help your successor with the transition and maybe even provide a little help after you've left so that you're on the best possible terms should you need to go back.

None of us is  watching the Taliban tighten the noose or trying to cross the channel on a lilo.

When I occasionally expressed anxiety about this sort of thing to my friends in the past they used to laugh at me because from where they were sitting it was obvious that I'd be fine. It's always obvious that other people will be fine it just never feels that way.

I don't know if it's really a good idea for you to quit your job if I'm honest - just because your record of making profits is relatively short. However you do decide to do that you could explain to your employer that you just don't need a job, offer a very long notice period, help your successor with the transition and maybe even provide a little help after you've left so that you're on the best possible terms should you need to go back.

text:
I'm only at just over 1x salary. As others have mentioned, a career gap on the CV is a big fear for me. And the usual fear of things stopping. 

However... I had a 3 month ago between jobs a couple of years ago. So I spent that time doing Betfair research. None of that led to further strategies and felt quite stressful. Doing the stuff part time is less stressful, and I used to get plenty of ideas while pondering on my daily commute or while taking a dump in the office.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text:
I'm only at just over 1x salary. As others have mentioned, a career gap on the CV is a big fear for me. And the usual fear of things stopping. 

However... I had a 3 month ago between jobs a couple of years ago. So I spent that time doing Betfair research. None of that led to further strategies and felt quite stressful. Doing the stuff part time is less stressful, and I used to get plenty of ideas while pondering on my daily commute or while taking a dump in the office.
